Award.AwardTitle: Opportunities, Mentoring, Education, Growth, and Academics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is awarding scholarships to academically talented students with financial need majoring in Engineering, Engineering Technology, Mathematics, Physics, or Computer Science. Program objectives include (1) employ recruitment efforts to expand the number of STEM students earning a bachelor's degree; (2) promote sustained, high quality faculty/student relationships between scholarship recipients and their faculty mentors; (3) increase these students' awareness of the academic support, career planning, and educational enhancement opportunities available to them and encourage them to utilize these resources and opportunities; (4) increase these students' awareness of and interaction with high technology industries and graduate education opportunities.

Recruitment efforts focus on high school, community college, and two-year college students in the five state region with an interest or aptitude in the STEM fields. Program components include extensive faculty mentoring and advising, contact with members of industry, educational enhancement activities, peer mentoring, and meetings of the scholarship recipients.

Intellectual Merit: The project is guided by current literature on student success as well as prior success with S-STEM projects that enable SDSU to continue and improve upon a successful scholarship program.

Broader Impact: The project provides an educational model that links existing student support systems and classroom learning with structured, out-of-the class experiences. Detailed strategies with frequent contact and monitoring of students early and throughout their college careers allow for greater retention of STEM students, which directly translates to impact on students and enables them to graduate with degrees in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of South Dakota State University’s NSF S-STEM program was to increase the enrollment and retention of academically talented, but financially needy students in high technology fields, and to better enable them to enter the workforce or graduate school. We awarded 68 scholarships in varying amounts of $3000, $4000, or $5000 per year--depending on the financial need of the student--and the scholarships were renewable annually until the recipient graduated, completed 4 years of full time study, or the grant period ended. Scholarships were awarded to undergraduate students majoring in engineering, mathematics, or computer science.

In order to improve the retention rates of our scholarship program participants and to better prepare them for the workforce or graduate school, the students participated in a variety of academic and support programs. The primary support tool we used was to have each participant meet regularly and often with a faculty member in their discipline in a student/mentor capacity. Participants also attended face-to-face meetings with members of industry relevant to the student’s field of study, attended themed group meetings with all scholarship recipients, participated in an academic club or organization, met with a peer mentor, and attended a variety of on-campus out of the classroom activities each semester.

The average GPA of each of our 68 participants taken from the last semester they were in the scholarship program was an impressive 3.55. Also, in the four years that we awarded scholarships, the number of applicants to our College of Engineering (which houses all of our S-STEM eligible disciplines) with an ACT score of 30 or more (top 4% in the nation) rose from 36 in 2013 to 56 in 2016, indicating that we were successful in selecting academically talented students for our scholarships and that the scholarship program may have had a positive influence in attracting academically strong students into our college of engineering.

Of our 68 scholarship program participants, 62 (91%) have graduated or were on track to graduate with a STEM degree at the time this report was written with an additional 2 participants who have graduated from SDSU with a non-STEM degree. These retention statistics are well above the university, regional, and national norms.

Our scholarships were primarily given to first year students so that we could use the awards as a recruiting tool. During the years of implementation of our S-STEM program, SDSU's College of Engineering had enrollment growth every year, experiencing a 14% increase in undergraduate enrollment going from 1399 undergraduates in 2012 to 1600 in 2017. This is some evidence that our program may also have had a positive influence on increasing the number of undergraduates studying STEM subjects at SDSU, whether they received an S-STEM scholarship or not.

Our S-STEM program was used to recruit students and enhance their college experience with programs that involved them in mentoring, communication with industry, conference participation, and enhanced academic training. The benefits to the college, university, and the United States through our program will augment both the STEM work force and academic world. Our program also acts as a model for other STEM programs seeking to increase recruitment, retention rates, and career preparation in these high technology areas.
